articles.title: The first browser with JavaScript landed 30 years ago
articles.description:
#â€‹754 â€” September 26, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Give Your AI Eyes: Introducing Chrome DevTools MCP â€” The Chrome team has released an MCP server for Chrome DevTools, enabling agents like Claude Code or OpenAI Codex to use the DevTools to debug and analyze the performance and behavior of your webapps (or even just to automate the use of Chrome generally). Addy does a great job of explaining the potentialÂ here.

Addy Osmani

AI Code Reviews Meet CLI Coding Agents â€” CodeRabbit CLI brings instant code reviews directly to your terminal, integrating with Claude Code, Cursor CLI, and other AI agents. While they generate code, CodeRabbit ensures it's production-ready - catching bugs, security issues, and hallucinations before they hit yourÂ codebase.

CodeRabbit sponsor

GitHub's Plan for a More Secure npm Supply Chain â€” In direct response to the recent npm ecosystem supply chain attacks of recent weeks, GitHubâ€™s senior director of security research has outlined steps GitHub is taking, including blocking the upload of packages featuring the patterns of the recent malware, hardening package publication, and promoting the use of trustedÂ publishing.

Xavier RenÃ©-Corail (GitHub)

IN BRIEF:

  • Netscape Navigator 2.0 Beta was released 30 years ago â€“ it was notable as the first browser to include JavaScript support.

  • The agenda of this week's TC39 meeting where several proposals were advanced, including Import Bytes, Iterator Chunking, and Array.prototype.pushAll.

  • The Chrome team expects Chrome/Chromium's support for the Temporal API to land in Chromium 144 (the current stable version is 140).

  • InfoQ shares an update on the features of Preact 11 beta, the recently released update to the popular lightweight ReactÂ alternative.

  • The IEEE has released its list of the top programming languages of 2025 with JavaScript and TypeScript coming in at #6 and #7Â respectively.

RELEASES:

  • pnpm 10.17 â€“ The new minimumReleaseAgeExclude now supports patterns to exclude groups of packages from minimum release ageÂ checks.

  • Astro 5.14 - Boasts "a bumper harvest of features and DX improvements to warm the cockles of your heart."

  • Node.js v24.9.0 (Current) and v22.20.0 (LTS)

  • Nuxt UI 4.0, PostgreSQL 18.0, ESLint v9.36.0

However, Capâ€™n Webâ€™s underlying serialization is human-readable, focused on integrating well with JS runtimes, and works over HTTP, WebSocket, and postMessage() out-of-the-box.

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸš€ Next week: JetBrains JavaScript Day 2025! A free online event full of talks & live Q&A with experts from the JS community. Donâ€™t missÂ it!

ğŸ§Â Learning web development with Dr.Â Axel

Over the past couple of months the esteemed Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has been working on a valuable series of beginner-friendly posts on a range of web development topics, with a heavy focus on JavaScript. He pitches the series as a way to teach people "who have never programmed how to create web apps with JavaScript".

These are all excellent primers/refreshers, and ideal for sharing with those early in their web development journey. Here are some of the highlights so far:

  • Working with numbers, variables, and functions, and strings and methods.
  • Booleans, comparisons and if statements and loops.
  • Digging into plain objects, Arrays, Maps, and exceptions.
  • An introduction to frontend frameworks using Preact.
  • Installing npm packages and bundling.
  • Promises and async functions.

P.S. Don't go JSON waterfalls..
